_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan document has been developed for SAFEWAY located at 3520 Pacific Avenue S., Auburn, WA  98001. This document has been prepared to satisfy the following regulations:



Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.



The purpose of this document is to:



1. Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.



2. Assist Safeway and local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.





This document summarizes Safeway's administrative and operational programs to prevent chemical-related accidents and reduce potential risks. These programs are detailed in the facility's Risk Management Program documentation.



The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is ammonia. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant for the purposes of food storage.  Safeway Inc. is the owner and operator of the facility and the ammonia refrigeration system.



Documentation



The RMP document summarizes the prevention programs and technical studies that formulate the RMP at the facility for safe handling of ammonia. At the beginning of the RMP documents, are the Documentation Record and  Record of Revision, and Revision Page Summary forms. The Documentation Record outlines all parties that have a copy of the respective document. Updates to this document will be provided to all parties listed on this record. The Record of Revision form should be used to indicate that the revisions have been included. When revision pages are provided a Revision Page Summary will be provided that outlines each added or replaced. 

 

Executive Summary



The following sections are required by the EPA Risk Management Program regulation, 40 CFR Part 68. 



A. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Polici

es



Safeway is dedicated to operation of a safe facility for its employees and neighboring community. A safety committee has been established that is responsible for the implementation of the safety program and an Emergency Response Plan.  This includes safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. Safeway has prepared risk and safety programs to ensure safe handling of the ammonia in the refrigeration system. Recently Safeway Inc. conducted a Process Hazard Analysis to identify potential hazards and the appropriate mitigation measures. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



1. The Safeway facility is located at 3520 Pacific Ave S in Auburn, Washington. The facility started operations at this location in 2005. Ammonia (NH3) is being used as the refrigerant. The total quantity of ammonia was calculated to be 63,000 pounds. 



2. The Safeway ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again. The system, consisting of piping, valves and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for product and process equipment. 



3. Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature: lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature. Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat. Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize. Heat is later removed from the ammonia as it is condensed back into a liquid. Typical operating conditions range from approximately 0 psig on the low-pressure side of each system to 185 psig on the high side. 



4. Ammonia is the regulated substance at this facility.



5. The maximum inventory of ammonia at the facility is 58,500 pounds.



Safeway has an accidental release prevention progra

m in place that complies with OSHA's 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management Standard. The International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's (IIAR) "Guide to the Implementation of Process Safety Management (PSM) for Ammonia Refrigeration" was as one of several sources to implement the PSM program at the Facility. Parts of the program include:



1. Employee Participation

2. Process Safety Information

3. Process Safety Hazard Analysis (PHA)

4. Operating Procedures

5. Training

6. Contractor Requirements

7. Pre Start-up Safety Review

8. Mechanical Integrity Audits

9. Hot Work Permits

10. Management of Change

11. Incident Investigation

12. Emergency Planning and Response

13. Compliance Audits



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An investigation into the facility's accident history reveals that there have been no significant releases of ammonia that met the EPA RMP definition of "accident" in the last five years (January 2015 - January 2020).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency action plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility:



  1.) To save lives.

  2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

  3.) To protect the environment.

  4.) To minimize property damage.



The facility maintains a safety committee whose members include the designated incident commander for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM/RMP regulations.



Facility personnel receive annual training regardin

g the emergency procedures.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger.  The plant manager will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Response Plan.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The most recent Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, was conducted for the produce warehouse on January 14-15, 2020.  The PHA study provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  The safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1.  Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.  Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.  Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.  Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
